Why I’m Excited to Switch from WordPress to Substack

Published on January 6, 2025

For years, WordPress has been the gold standard for building websites and managing content. It offers endless customization, powerful plugins, and complete control over your site. But as my needs evolve, I’m realizing that simplicity and focus matter more than unlimited options. That’s where Substack comes in.

Quick note: If you are already subscribed to Win The Night, you should start receiving our Substack emails instead, starting this week.

Here’s why I think Substack is better for what I’m building—and why I’m excited to make the switch:

1. Streamlined Publishing

WordPress is incredible for complex websites, but it can feel overwhelming for simple tasks like writing and publishing. Substack removes all that friction. Its interface is clean, distraction-free, and built specifically for writing. I can focus on my content without getting lost in plugins, themes, or constant updates.

2. Built-In Email Distribution

WordPress excels at websites, but email newsletters require third-party plugins or platforms. With Substack, email is baked in. Every post I publish is instantly delivered to my subscribers’ inboxes, which simplifies my workflow and strengthens the connection with my audience.

3. Monetization Made Easy

WordPress gives you full control over monetization, but that also means setting up payment processors, membership plugins, and managing it all yourself. Substack handles subscriptions seamlessly, making it easy to offer paid content without the technical headaches.

4. Community and Engagement

Substack encourages more interaction through comments, reactions, and an email-driven relationship. WordPress can do this too, but it often requires extra tools and isn’t as natural. Substack’s focus on community makes it feel like you’re truly building a connection, not just running a blog.

5. Less Maintenance

Running a WordPress site means dealing with hosting, security, backups, and troubleshooting. Substack takes care of all of that. No more worrying about a plugin breaking your site or hackers targeting your login page—it’s all handled for you.

6. Focus on Writing

At the end of the day, I’m switching to Substack because it’s built for writers. WordPress is great for creating anything, but it’s easy to get distracted by design tweaks, widgets, and endless customization. Substack strips all of that away and lets me focus on my message.

Why I’m Excited to Switch

Switching to Substack feels like decluttering my creative life. It’s a chance to focus on what really matters: creating great content and connecting with my audience. I’m not just excited about simplifying my workflow—I’m also looking forward to experimenting with Substack’s built-in tools for growth and monetization.

This move isn’t just about convenience; it’s about aligning my platform with my priorities. Substack feels like a tool that will grow with me while keeping things simple, efficient, and focused on what I love most, creating killer content.

I’ll still be using WordPress for my personal site, but from now on all Win The Night will be handled via Substack.

Ready to follow along? Subscribe to my Substack publication, Win The Night, and join the journey today!
